newsitem.title: FRANCE: French shares remain jittery in wake of EMU talks.
newsitem.headline: French shares remain jittery in wake of EMU talks.

text.p: French shares remained jittery but traded above their lows after they had been dented by new French Finance Minister Dominique Strauss-Kahn telling European ministers in Luxembourg France needed time to discuss the stability pact with its National Assembly.

Finance Ministers, in particular Germany, had wanted an agreement on the stability pact -- calling for harmonised budget policies in parallel with monetary policy -- ahead of the June 16 and 17 summit of heads of state in Amsterdam.
German diplomats said they remain confident that the stability pact could be signed by the end of June.
Strauss-Kahn said he was committed to EMU but needed at least a week to discuss the stability pact.
Iain Lindsay of Credit Lyonnais said that the Socialist government had still not stated its position but was keeping its powder dry.

A market strategist at Paribas said that the Socialist government's first act on the international scene showed that it was not the kind of "free-market socialists" some Anglo-Saxon investors had been hoping for with the example of the British labour government. He expected volatility to remain until Prime Minister Lionel Jospin's policy declaration expected on June 17.
* CAC-40 index down 49.45, or 1.82 percent, at 2,669.8 at 1212 GMT.
* CAC-40 June futures 2,654 vs 2,700 at Friday's close.
* Bouygues, up 0.58 percent at 522 francs, only blue-chip to rise after obtaining financing for telecoms plans last week.
